awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Semiconductor Surfaces and Catalyst Interfaces for Water Oxidation with Solar Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
Sunlight is the largest energy resource available on Earth. Harvesting even a small fraction of the sunlight striking the United States would help our country become energy independent. There are several factors which limit full utilization of sunlight to meet our energy needs. For example, sunlight is intermittent while our energy demands are nearly constant.  Also, it is difficult to use solar energy directly to meet some of our needs, such as transportation fuels. These factors motivate efforts to convert solar energy into chemical fuels, often referred to as solar fuels. Water is one of the most abundant chemicals available on Earth, and a reaction known as oxidation enables the energy of the sun to convert water into useful forms of energy (electrons and protons). Scientists currently do not fully understand the processes which control solar-powered water oxidation. In this project, Dr. Hamann is investigating the fundamental steps of water oxidation on semiconductor surfaces that absorb sunlight. Catalysts deposited on those surfaces use the absorbed solar energy to oxidize water. Dr. Hamann is also engaged in several outreach activities that leverage his research activities.  These activities engage the public and students at all levels in the scientific challenges associated with solar energy capture and conversion to useful forms of energy (like solar fuels). These activities include participation in the Michigan State University Science Festival, a series of Science Café's focused on sustainability, the Midwestern Symposium on Undergraduate Research, and the American Chemical Society (ACS) Project SEED for economically disadvantaged high school students.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Hamann of Michigan State University (MSU) is investigating photo-induced water oxidation with metal oxide semiconductors. Surface states, both defect and photo-induced species, play a dominant role in controlling the efficiency of water oxidation on metal oxide semiconductors. A suite of electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, spectroscopic and operando measurements are being carried out to elucidate the nature and behaviour of these surface states during solar water oxidation on ternary metal oxide electrodes, including copper tungstate, CuWO4. Integration of water oxidation catalysts on semiconductor surfaces is a promising method to improve the water oxidation efficiency, however the nature of the interface that develops between semiconductor and catalyst, and its effect on the electron-transfer reactions occurring at this interface, is not well understood.  Several semiconductor/catalyst combinations are also being investigated to develop a general and detailed understanding of the role of the interface in controlling the overall water oxidation reaction. The knowledge gained from this research allows the development of efficient conversion of solar energy to high energy density chemical fuels, which is a significant benefit to society. Additional broader impacts of this research derive from Dr. Hamann's outreach and educational activities at all levels.  These activities increases interest, understanding and participation of underrepresented minorities in this area of science. Specific outreach efforts include participation in the MSU Science Festival, the Midwestern Symposium on Undergraduate Research, a series of Science Café's focused on sustainability, and the ACS Project SEED.

por.por_cntn:
The project was motivated by the possibility of using metal oxide semiconductors composed of earth-abundant elements to harness sunlight and use the energy to split water into hydrogen and oxygen gasses. As a result, the intermittent and diffuse solar energy resource is concentrated and stored as hydrogen, termed a solar fuel. A significant bottleneck in the efficiency of making solar fuels is the water oxidation half reaction on semiconductor surfaces which competes with charge recombination losses. We have therefore focused on integrating water oxidation co-catalysts (WOC) on the semiconductor surfaces in order to improve the water oxidation efficiency.

 

WOC’s have been integrated with a variety of metal oxide photoanodes and were observed to improve the performance, largely reflected in a more favorable photocurrent onset potential. There have been many prior reports in the literature of numerous semiconductors / catalyst combinations investigated with different methodologies which has led to different interpretations regarding the nature of the improvement observed. We therefore set out to employ a variety of electrochemical and photoelectrochemical methods to systematically interrogate a variety of catalysts on semiconductor electrodes prepared with different morphologies, doping and crystallinity to reconcile the different interpretations and develop a more general understanding of this interfacial reaction. We have firmly established that photogenerated holes in all forms of hematite are quantitatively transferred to catalysts (FexNiyOz, CoOx) and water oxidation proceeds directly from the catalyst. As a result, this charge separation circumvents surface state recombination which we attribute to the cause of the improved performance.

 

We have also discovered that when the semiconductor electrode is porous, the catalyst can contact the back conductive substrate directly which causes a shunting pathway, which is problematic for conductive catalysts. We believe this result explains some of the other interpretations of the effect of WOC’s previously reported in the literature. Since this shunting pathway is problematic for conductive catalysts, which are the majority of good WOCs, we followed up this finding by selectively electrodepositing a thin polymer film (PPO) in between the semiconductor and catalyst to physically block this shunting path. We believe this is a powerful general strategy which can not only prevent shunting but protect unstable electrodes as well. 

 

Interestingly, we have found that with copper tungstate electrodes, no clear improved performance in solar water oxidation was observed upon the addition of any WOCs. This is even though we have shown surface state recombination is a limiting reaction as it is for other semiconductors, and that holes are collected by the many WOCs we have integrated with copper tungstate. Even in the absence of shunting, however, catalysts appear to be ineffective. Interestingly, we found that holes are transfered from the copper tungstate to WOCs, but the catalyst potential unable to support water oxidation. This catalyst potential is the same as surface states we identified at the copper tungstate surface. Thus, we believe we have demonstrated the first unambiguous example of catalyst layer fermi level pinning to a semiconductor surface state. The water oxidation reaction must therefore occur at the copper tungstate surface. This tentative explanation is the subject of ongoing investigations.

 

In another branch of our NSF supported research, we aimed to expand our investigation of photoanode materials to nitrides, with Ta3N5 as the prototypical example. While Ta3N5 is a very promising semiconducotr, it requires a high temperature (ca. 1,000 C) to synthesize it under harsh conditions which prevents production of tandem devices needed to achieve overall water splitting. We therefore aimed to synthesize crystalline Ta3N5 at low temperatures via a home-built atomic layer deposition (ALD) instrument. We showed that the growth mode (crystallinity, morphology, topography, and growth rate) of Ta3N5 films strongly depends on the number of ALD cycles and the substrate. The variation in the growth mode was attributed to the crystal mismatch between the substrate and crystalline Ta3N5. This observation readily opens up new opportunities to utilize ALD to deposit films of Ta3N5 with controllable crystallographic properties and precise thicknesses by simply modifying the substrate.

 

In addition to the scientific advances, several graduate students – including underrepresented students – were supported by this project and received extensive training in material synthesis, characterization, electrochemistry, spectroscopy, solar energy conversion and catalysis. The synthesis of semiconductors is an area of national need, and thus vital to have highly trained and skilled scientists in the workforce. These students were also able to attend national scientific meetings and give poster and oral presentations on their work. The PI developed and teaches a graduate course on the physics and chemistry of solar energy conversion to more generally train graduate students in energy and materials sciences. The PI gave many invited talks at national and international conferences related to materials and solar fuels research and was the organizer of an international solar fuels meeting, and participated in numerous outreach activities.
